Divided by the earnings ratio
So one method of valuing a stock or the stock market is to determine what the PE ratio the price earnings ratio is and then to compare that with
Historical norms and then also to compare that with some of the critical variables that have an impact on the P. E. ratio most especially things like inflation expectations and interest rates
So when we take a look at the historical range of PE ratios as they would apply for example to the standard and Poor's five hundred index we see that over the very very long term the range has been quite wide
For example back in Nineteen Seventy four when the stock market was in the throes of a brutal bear market that lasted for close to two full years
Because the bear market back then that led to that very very low historical valuation figure started in January of Nineteen Seventy three in fact it started
Right at the same time that the peace treaty was signed with North Vietnam bringing an end to the war in Vietnam so we're back to January Seventy three and the market right at the time the peace treaty is signed
Editors bear market and by the end of Nineteen Seventy four nearly a full two years later like twenty three months later
The market finally reaches its final bottom in December of Nineteen Seventy four and the interesting thing about this is the valuation level on a price to earnings ratio basis that prevailed at the end of Nineteen Seventy four at the end of that brutal bear market
The ... the ratio was basically the lowest ever the market was trading and I speak of the S. and P. five hundred index here was trading basically at seven times earnings and so that was an extremely low level of valuation
And then we have the polar opposite which is the record high level of evaluation for the U.S and the five hundred into action that occurred back in the early part of the new millennium in fact it occurred in January two thousand
And January two thousand
The ah to march of two thousand call it the first quarter of year two thousand
We saw the price to earnings ratio on the standard and Poor's five hundred index escalate to a record high which was basically thirty times earnings think about this now in December of Nineteen Seventy four at the bottom of the massive bear market that lasted almost two years
We had a valuation of seven times earnings on a price to earnings ratio bases
Well look at that extreme and the first quarter of two thousand when you had that level up to basically thirty times earnings that is more than four times greater
Than the low evaluation that prevailed
At the bottom of the Nineteen Seventy three Nineteen Seventy four bear market
So there we have a range including the extremes of the range so we can mark down okay
We have a say you're seven and December Seventy four basically that's his lowest it's been historically this is for the U.S and the five hundred index and then we have the figure of thirty in the first quarter of year two thousand
And that's the highest it's been
For the U.S and the five hundred index so we could call that the total range including the extreme low in the extreme high
Then we have a range of normalcy and the range of normalcy would be in the mid to on occasion the upper teens
Certainly a range of normalcy would be in the Fifteen to sixteen times earnings range however
During extended bull markets you can see a slightly higher range of normalcy which can reach as high as Seventeen to Eighteen times earnings now
This gives you an idea of what to expect most of the time
Most of the time you're going to have a price earnings ratio is going to be from the mid to the upper teens something in the general area of Fifteen times earnings
Ranging up to something in the general area of Eighteen times earnings and that is how you can determine what the valuation of the market is relative to its historical record
Obviously inflation is very important here because the higher the rate of inflation than ah the um the last
Uh integrity is given to future earnings because the future earnings are degraded because of inflation because of the degradation of buying power that results due to inflation
Obviously in a low inflation inflation environment or that is good for a price to earnings ratios because those future earnings are worth more when inflation rates are low

We are back on Monday talk thank you for joining us
And certainly on our broadcast over the years we have discussed some some some critical factors that you can incorporate into your investment management to help you along the way and we've talked in detail about a number of these not the least of which is diversification
Where you are diversifying your portfolio money over a many different investments not putting all of your eggs in one basket and we've talked in detail and you know it's something that's come up and that is the issue of how much money you put it in any one stock how many times can you recall
That people have called into the broadcast investors have called in and said well you know I have all my money in the stock or most of my money or whatever
And it's just not good investments sense to do that because what you do when you concentrate your investments in one stock did you expose yourself to something that is known as specific company risk
And specific company risk is a big deal if you focus on just one company
If something goes wrong with the business model or in some other way something goes wrong with your company like Enron for example than the money's gone and that's the reason that we have talked so many years about our four percent guideline
And our four percent guideline is basically an offshoot of modern portfolio theory that's all it is and in modern portfolio theory it has been documented that if you own twenty five stocks
A lot different than all your money in one or two stocks if you own twenty five stocks with an application of about four percent or a full portfolio as soon as you're doing your own stock picking if you owned twenty five stocks
Across many different industries not twenty five drugs stocks not twenty five tech stocks only five stocks across many different industries
That what you can do in that portfolio is you can achieve a level of diversification
That will avoid this problem of all my wanting in money and wants to all my money in one industry group and that is really a very very strong tenet of investment management that idea of diversification and then there's asset allocation especially
Someone that's approaching or in their retirement years
Asset allocation makes so much sense where they're going to adopt a balanced investment portfolio or they're going to have a portion of their portfolio allocated to the stock market
And that includes a portion of that in the international community stock market and then they're going to have a portion of their investment portfolio in the fixed income area
And there are many different ways to invest in fixed income securities and many of those are government guaranteed like FDIC insured CDs or treasury instruments
So asset allocation is another of the key tenets of investment management keeping expenses as low as something we've talked about on this broadcast for more than a quarter century because when you keep those expenses low on your portfolio
That means that there's more money going into your pocket and less money going into an advisors pocket and that's good because you wind up with more money at the end of the day
And so keeping expenses down is a big deal and you know a good part of that can be done by incorporating something we've talked about and that's including index funds in your portfolio index funds might be the total stock market index that might be the S. and P. five hundred they might be the um
That they might be the Russell three thousand but index funds can go a long way to doing two things virtually keeping your expenses down which is great and secondly guaranteeing you you're not going to under perform you cannot under perform [noise] on the index portion of a portfolio [noise]

So many other things that are keys we've talked about saving a minimum if you can afford to do so a minimum of ten percent of your income
Because that's the money that you're going to invest in your um IRA or your four one K. or your four oh three baby or tax privilege to count whatever it may be
And that's the money that over time can compound and grow for you until you reach retirement age level now
I liked the idea of putting more than ... percent frankly if you can afford to put a Fifteen Percent or twenty percent more power to you

At a minimum level if you can afford to do so I Would establish ten percent as that minimum now another topic that we've talked about that so critical is paying those credit cards off on a monthly basis because you accomplished two things
When you pay your credit cards off on a monthly basis number one you don't accumulate some massive usually high interest
Rate debt that you really don't want as part of your future financial picture you don't do that when you pay them all monthly but the second thing that happens is it works as a discipline on avoiding excessive spending
Because if you cannot afford to pay it off on a monthly basis then all you're doing is piling up debt something that I Know many of you may not want to do
Another thing that I think is important and you know when you listen to the money talks colors you hear that a lot of people have some work to do on this one and that is when you're approaching or in your retirement years
You really want to think about a balanced investment portfolio now a balanced investment portfolio edits basic form
As a fifty percent allegations of the stock market and the fifty percent allocation to income producing securities
And the whole idea about using a balanced portfolio approaching or in your retirement years is to manage your risk
You don't want to be taking a lot of risk when you're at that point in the investment cycle and the way for you to modify that risk control that risk managed it if you will is by adopting a balanced investment portfolio
That contains an equal amount or close to an equal amount in stock market investments highly diversified of course
And an income producing security's so that's a thought that I think is that the core of investing which is the adoption of a balanced investment portfolio approach approaching or in your retirement years
And these are are some of the key things that I think that you can do to make a difference
